title: Drunken dad-of-one banned from airline for LIFE after going 'purple with rage' on flight
text:
Get daily   Thank you for subscribing!   
A dad-of-one has been banned from an airline for life after drunkenly shoving a stewardess when he was refused eight cans of Stella Artois. 
Lance Wheelwright, 33, was on a Flybe plane to Manchester following a boozy trip to Amsterdam when he lost his temper, assaulted a crew member and racially abused a fellow passenger. 
When cabin crew gave him three beers - for himself and two friends - rather than the eight he demanded, he became ‘purple with rage’, a court heard. 
Prosecuting, Duncan Wilcock, said as the plane was preparing to land on November 10 last year, Wheelwright was abusive to a cabin crew member, calling her a ‘f bitch.’ 
As passengers were leaving the aircraft, Wheelwright then told her, ‘Move bitch’ and pushed her. Read More easyJet flight forced to return to Manchester Airport following bird strike 
Mr Wilcock told Manchester’s Minshull Street Crown Court: “With both hands out in front of him, he pushed (her) to the chest. She staggered backwards but managed to remain on her feet.” 
A passenger tried to intervene, but Wheelwright shouted at him: “Mind your own business you fat Australian c***.” 
He then threatened to kill another member of the cabin crew. Flybe has announced new routes to Bournemouth and Bergerac 
Mr Wilcock added: “The company has banned him for life from flying with them in the future. This is the first time such an order has been placed by this airline.” 
A victim impact statement from one of the crew, read out in court, said: “In 16 years I have dealt with drunken and disruptive passengers. What I experienced on this occasion was the first time I have ever been spoken to in this manner or been physically assaulted.” 
She added that there would have been ‘devastating consequences’ if the plane was in the air at the time. 
Wheelwright, of Whiston, Merseyside, pleaded guilty to one count of assault, one count of using threatening words or behaviour and one count of using racially aggravated threatening words or behaviour at an earlier magistrates’ court hearing. Lance Wheelwright
